channel.title: Java 7?
channel.description: Sounds like Java 7 may finally start confronting the problems with Java 5 Generics. http://www.javapolis.com/confluence/download/attachments/32797/LangChange-DSCF3611.JPG

item.title: Java 7?
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Meh, the CONCEPT of generics is easy, but utilizing them is a real bitch.

Read full topic

item.title: Java 7?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

looking back at my java ebook, i learned parameterised types before i learned what a stream of bytes was, about multiple threads / object monitors, and sockets.

still though, i didn’t learn about generic methods until a bit later.

so i guess, easy to learn, hard to master

Read full topic

item.title: Java 7?
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

generics are easy, they are just bad

Read full topic

item.title: Java 7?
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:4, topic:171508”]the top-left idea looks like a shortcut for making getter/setter methods

like when you do “string part1” + myObjectInstance + " string part 2", it invokes the toString() method on myObjectInstance, but its just a shortcut

those programmers have bad handwriting… ah who am i to talk… mines is worse then that xD[/quote]
Its more then a shortcut, one can override the gets and sets.
so when i do class.property = value, a set method is invoked.

Most imporant thing i believe is generics. Generics need to be changed.

Power point presentation:
http://www.javac.info/bloch-closures-controversy.ppt

The board lists how i cannot define 2 functions in the same class. I have run into this issue recently and it is show stopper.
doStuff(List)
doStuff(List)

Also i can not do
List
No primitve type support therefore generics are handled entirly at the bytecode level not the vm level.

Also Generics are complex, probably one of the last things people learn in Java.
http://weblogs.java.net/blog/arnold/archive/2005/06/generics_consid_1.html

Read full topic

item.title: Java 7?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Multicatch could be handy, but at the end of the day it’s not something that really matters.
Adding support for String objects in switch statements would be good in the sense that it cuts down on code.

Buuuuuut, why did the -> operator get a mention? That would be an extremely strange addition.

Read full topic

i, too, would like operator overloading, but i suppose it is all just cosmetic
